trans-unit.source: Service Fabric application deployment
trans-unit.target: Service Fabric application deployment

trans-unit.source: How to deploy and remove applications in Service Fabric
trans-unit.target: How to deploy and remove applications in Service Fabric

trans-unit.source: Deploy an application
trans-unit.target: Deploy an application

trans-unit.source: Once an [application type has been packaged][10], it's ready for deployment into a Service Fabric cluster.
trans-unit.target: Once an [application type has been packaged][10], it's ready for deployment into a Service Fabric cluster.

trans-unit.source: Deployment involves the following three steps:
trans-unit.target: Deployment involves the following three steps:

trans-unit.source: Uploading the application package
trans-unit.target: Uploading the application package

trans-unit.source: Registering the application type
trans-unit.target: Registering the application type

trans-unit.source: Creating the application instance
trans-unit.target: Creating the application instance

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you use Visual Studio for deploying and debugging applications on your local development cluster, all of the steps described below are handled automatically by invoking the PowerShell scripts found in the Scripts folder of the application project.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you use Visual Studio for deploying and debugging applications on your local development cluster, all of the steps described below are handled automatically by invoking the PowerShell scripts found in the Scripts folder of the application project.

trans-unit.source: This article provides background on what those scripts are doing so that you can perform the same operations outside of Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: This article provides background on what those scripts are doing so that you can perform the same operations outside of Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Upload the application package
trans-unit.target: Upload the application package

trans-unit.source: Uploading the application package puts it in a location accessible by internal Service Fabric components and can be performed through PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: Uploading the application package puts it in a location accessible by internal Service Fabric components and can be performed through PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Before running any PowerShell commands in this article, always start by first connecting to the Service Fabric cluster using **Connect-ServiceFabricCluster**.
trans-unit.target: Before running any PowerShell commands in this article, always start by first connecting to the Service Fabric cluster using **Connect-ServiceFabricCluster**.

trans-unit.source: Suppose you have a folder named *MyApplicationType* containing the necessary application manifest, service manifest(s), and code/config/data package(s), then the **Copy-ServiceFabricApplicationPackage** command will upload the package.
trans-unit.target: Suppose you have a folder named *MyApplicationType* containing the necessary application manifest, service manifest(s), and code/config/data package(s), then the **Copy-ServiceFabricApplicationPackage** command will upload the package.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Register the application package
trans-unit.target: Register the application package

trans-unit.source: Registering the application package, makes the application type and version declared in the application manifest available for use.
trans-unit.target: Registering the application package, makes the application type and version declared in the application manifest available for use.

trans-unit.source: The system will read the package uploaded in the previous step, verify the package (equivalent to running **Test-ServiceFabricApplicationPackage** locally), process the package contents, and copy the processed package to an internal system location.
trans-unit.target: The system will read the package uploaded in the previous step, verify the package (equivalent to running **Test-ServiceFabricApplicationPackage** locally), process the package contents, and copy the processed package to an internal system location.

trans-unit.source: The **Register-ServiceFabricApplicationType** command returns only after the application package has been successfully copied by the system.
trans-unit.target: The **Register-ServiceFabricApplicationType** command returns only after the application package has been successfully copied by the system.

trans-unit.source: How long this takes depends on the contents of the application package.
trans-unit.target: How long this takes depends on the contents of the application package.

trans-unit.source: The **-TimeoutSec** parameter can be used to supply a longer timeout if needed (the default timeout is 60 seconds).
trans-unit.target: The **-TimeoutSec** parameter can be used to supply a longer timeout if needed (the default timeout is 60 seconds).

trans-unit.source: The **Get-ServiceFabricApplicationType** command will list all successfully registered application type versions.
trans-unit.target: The **Get-ServiceFabricApplicationType** command will list all successfully registered application type versions.

trans-unit.source: Create the application
trans-unit.target: Create the application

trans-unit.source: An application can be instantiated using any application type version that has been registered successfully using the **New-ServiceFabricApplication** command.
trans-unit.target: An application can be instantiated using any application type version that has been registered successfully using the **New-ServiceFabricApplication** command.

trans-unit.source: The name of each application must start with the *fabric:* scheme and be unique for each application instance.
trans-unit.target: The name of each application must start with the *fabric:* scheme and be unique for each application instance.

trans-unit.source: If there were any default services defined in the application manifest of the target application type, then those will also be created at this time.
trans-unit.target: If there were any default services defined in the application manifest of the target application type, then those will also be created at this time.

trans-unit.source: The **Get-ServiceFabricApplication** command lists all applications instances that were successfully created along with their overall status.
trans-unit.target: The **Get-ServiceFabricApplication** command lists all applications instances that were successfully created along with their overall status.

trans-unit.source: The **Get-ServiceFabricService** command lists all service instances that were successfully created within a given application instance.
trans-unit.target: The **Get-ServiceFabricService** command lists all service instances that were successfully created within a given application instance.

trans-unit.source: Default services (if any) will be listed here.
trans-unit.target: Default services (if any) will be listed here.

trans-unit.source: Multiple application instances can be created for any given version of a registered application type.
trans-unit.target: Multiple application instances can be created for any given version of a registered application type.

trans-unit.source: Each application instance will run in isolation, with its own work directory and process.
trans-unit.target: Each application instance will run in isolation, with its own work directory and process.

trans-unit.source: Remove an application
trans-unit.target: Remove an application

trans-unit.source: When an application instance is no longer needed, it can be permanently removed using the **Remove-ServiceFabricApplication** command.
trans-unit.target: When an application instance is no longer needed, it can be permanently removed using the **Remove-ServiceFabricApplication** command.

trans-unit.source: This will automatically remove all services belonging to the application as well, permanently removing all service state.
trans-unit.target: This will automatically remove all services belonging to the application as well, permanently removing all service state.

trans-unit.source: This operation cannot be reversed and application state cannot be recovered.
trans-unit.target: This operation cannot be reversed and application state cannot be recovered.

trans-unit.source: When a particular version of an application type is no longer needed, it should be unregistered using the **Unregister-ServiceFabricApplicationType** command.
trans-unit.target: When a particular version of an application type is no longer needed, it should be unregistered using the **Unregister-ServiceFabricApplicationType** command.

trans-unit.source: Unregistering unused types will release storage space used by the application package contents of that type on the Image Store.
trans-unit.target: Unregistering unused types will release storage space used by the application package contents of that type on the Image Store.

trans-unit.source: An application type can be unregistered as long as there are no applications instantiated against it or pending application upgrades referencing it.
trans-unit.target: An application type can be unregistered as long as there are no applications instantiated against it or pending application upgrades referencing it.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting

trans-unit.source: Copy-ServiceFabricApplicationPackage asks for an ImageStoreConnectionString
trans-unit.target: Copy-ServiceFabricApplicationPackage asks for an ImageStoreConnectionString

trans-unit.source: The Service Fabric SDK environment should already have the correct defaults set up.
trans-unit.target: The Service Fabric SDK environment should already have the correct defaults set up.

trans-unit.source: But if needed, the ImageStoreConnectionString for all commands should match the value being used by the Service Fabric cluster, which can be found in the cluster manifest retrieved using the **Get-ServiceFabricClusterManifest** command:
trans-unit.target: But if needed, the ImageStoreConnectionString for all commands should match the value being used by the Service Fabric cluster, which can be found in the cluster manifest retrieved using the **Get-ServiceFabricClusterManifest** command:
